conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, analyze the acceleration vs. time graph and understand how it translates into velocity and position.
For 0 ≤ t ≤ t0/2, the acceleration a = a0 t / t0, representing a linear increase.
For t0/2 ≤ t ≤ t0, the acceleration is constant and equal to a0.
For t0 ≤ t ≤ 3t0/2, the acceleration decreases linearly to zero.
For 3t0/2 ≤ t ≤ 2t0, the acceleration is constant and equal to -a0.
The velocity v(t) can be found by integrating the acceleration with respect to time.
From 0 to t0/2, v(t) = a0 t^2 / (2 t0).
From t0/2 to t0, v(t) = a0 t.
From t0 to 3t0/2, v(t) = -a0 t + a0 t0.
The position x(t) can be found by integrating the velocity with respect to time.
From 0 to t0/2, x(t) = a0 t^3 / (6 t0).
From t0/2 to t0, x(t) = a0 t^2 / 2.
From t0 to 3t0/2, x(t) = -a0 t^2 / 2 + a0 t0 t.
